questions.text: How do you define winning culture inside the building?

A.text: Non‑negotiable standards, routines, and accountability before anything else.

B.text: Player-led energy and freedom; let stars set the tone and keep it loose.

questions.text: If a star player violates team rules the week of a big game, what do you do?

A.text: Bench him if necessary—standards don’t change based on status.

B.text: Handle it privately; keep him available and protect the locker-room mood.

questions.text: What should drive our identity year to year?

A.text: Continuity—build a recognizable system and evolve it incrementally.

B.text: Adaptation—rebuild the scheme around roster strengths every offseason.

questions.text: What timeline do you expect before we judge the regime?

A.text: Multi-year plan; I’ll earn trust through process and steady improvement.

B.text: Fast turnaround; push every lever immediately to win now.

questions.text: What role should analytics play in football decisions?

A.text: Support tool—use data to confirm coaching judgment, not replace it.

B.text: Driver—use models to dictate aggressiveness, personnel, and play calls.

questions.text: After a bad loss, what’s your approach with the media?

A.text: Shield players, own the outcome, keep messaging consistent and boring.

B.text: Control the narrative; be direct, emotional, and set the agenda publicly.

questions.text: How aggressive are you on 4th down?

A.text: Situational—protect field position unless the math is overwhelming.

B.text: Aggressive by default—be the team that dictates terms.

questions.text: What’s your cap/contract philosophy?

A.text: Avoid future dead money; flexible structures; pay for sustained performance.

B.text: Push money forward if it buys wins; restructure aggressively to compete.

questions.text: If your OC and DC can’t coexist, what happens?

A.text: I set hierarchy and expectations; conflict ends or someone goes.

B.text: Let them battle it out; competition sharpens the building.

questions.text: How do you handle a young QB struggling early?

A.text: Protect him with structure and reps; development over short-term optics.

B.text: Let him throw; trial by fire; if he can’t handle it, pivot quickly.

questions.text: Do you prefer keeping staff stable even after a mediocre season?

A.text: Yes—continuity compounds; fix issues within the same system.

B.text: No—replace underperformers quickly; loyalty is earned weekly.

questions.text: How do you treat long-tenured veterans near the end?

A.text: With respect—clear roles, dignified exits, no surprises.

B.text: Coldly—if production drops, move on immediately.

questions.text: How often should we shop players publicly?

A.text: Rarely—keep negotiations private to preserve trust.

B.text: Often—use the market noise to create leverage.

questions.text: How do you want ownership involvement to work?

A.text: Clear lanes—ownership sets principles; football ops runs football.

B.text: High-touch—ownership in the room for major roster decisions.

questions.text: Who should be the public face: coach, GM, or shared?
Draft approach?

A.text: Safe floor early, development later; minimize bust risk.

B.text: Swing for upside early; accept busts to find stars.

questions.text: How do you enforce discipline day-to-day?

B.text: Case-by-case; read the room; keep morale high.

questions.text: Would you ever overhaul scheme in Year 1?

A.text: Only if absolutely necessary; prefer incremental installs.

B.text: Yes—install my identity immediately regardless of friction.

questions.text: Role of players in decisions?

A.text: Voice, not veto—respect input but keep hierarchy.

questions.text: What matters more: legacy or weekly edge?

A.text: Legacy—protect the institution and its standards.

B.text: Edge—whatever wins this week; tradition is optional.

questions.text: In Round 1, do you prioritize floor or ceiling?
In free agency, do you pay premium or shop bargains?
How do you handle questionable stars on short weeks?
How do you choose team captains?
How do you integrate scouting reports into weekly plans?
How large is your weekly install?
How quickly do you pivot when a plan fails?
How do you reduce penalties?
How do you talk about turnovers?
How much do you value special teams edge?
How do you use sports science / workload tracking?
Do you buy or sell at the deadline?
Do rookies start immediately or earn snaps?
Do you rest vets in practice?
Do you ever call out players publicly?
Do you fit scheme to players or players to scheme?
How do you handle clock management responsibilities?
How aggressive are you on challenges?
What does self-scout look like?
How do you handle opponent tendencies?
Red zone philosophy?
3rd down philosophy?
Two-minute philosophy?
Short yardage identity?
Goal-line approach?
How do you hire coordinators?
How do you delegate weekly responsibilities?
How do you build development plans?
How do you grade players week to week?
How do you evaluate your staff?
How do you define winning culture inside the building?

A.text: Non‑negotiable standards, routines, and accountability before anything else.

B.text: Player-led energy and freedom; let stars set the tone and keep it loose.

B.text: Push money forward if it buys wins; restructure aggressively to compete.

questions.text: If your OC and DC can’t coexist, what happens?

A.text: I set hierarchy and expectations; conflict ends or someone goes.

B.text: Let them battle it out; competition sharpens the building.

questions.text: How do you handle a young QB struggling early?

A.text: Protect him with structure and reps; development over short-term optics.

B.text: Let him throw; trial by fire; if he can’t handle it, pivot quickly.

questions.text: How do you use press conferences?

A.text: Set narrative, motivate, apply pressure publicly.

B.text: Keep it minimal and internal; no theatrics.

questions.text: Do you lean into star marketing?

A.text: Yes—spotlight stars; build brand; accept some ego.

questions.text: Would you trade two 1sts for a star?

A.text: If it changes perception and wins now, yes.

B.text: Only if it’s clearly under market; otherwise no.

questions.text: When do you fire a coordinator?

A.text: Immediately if narrative turns; don’t let rot spread.

B.text: End of season unless truly toxic.

questions.text: How do you react to fan backlash?

A.text: Engage—answer it, redirect it, own the story.

B.text: Ignore it; fans don’t run football.

questions.text: Late game: up 3, 4th & 2 at midfield—go?

A.text: Go—win with aggression; finish the story.

B.text: Punt—make them drive; avoid headline mistakes.

questions.text: What’s your message after embarrassing loss?

A.text: Public accountability + urgency; call it out.

B.text: Keep it inside; protect confidence; move on.

questions.text: What identity sells?
Is your personal brand an asset?

A.text: Yes—use it; be visible; control perception.

B.text: No—let results speak; stay low profile.

questions.text: How do you handle ownership pressure?

A.text: I thrive on it; I’ll raise the temperature.

B.text: I prefer calm process; pressure hurts decisions.

questions.text: How do you handle a young QB struggling early?

A.text: Protect him with structure and reps; development over short-term optics.

B.text: Let him throw; trial by fire; if he can’t handle it, pivot quickly.

questions.text: What benchmarks do you use to evaluate progress?

A.text: Clear KPIs weekly: efficiency, penalties, win-prob leverage.

B.text: Feel-based; trust the process and locker room vibe.

questions.text: If injuries hit, what’s the expectation?

A.text: No excuses; adjust and hit targets anyway.

questions.text: How do you handle an assistant who misses details?

A.text: Replace quickly; details are the job.

B.text: Coach them up; give them runway.

questions.text: Practice style?

A.text: High-tempo, high standards; competition every period.

B.text: Player-friendly; manage load; keep bodies fresh.

questions.text: What triggers are unacceptable?

A.text: Repeated procedural errors: penalties, missed fits, busted coverages.

questions.text: If QB regresses, what do you do?

A.text: Immediate intervention: mechanics, staff changes, simplify plan.

B.text: Stay course; trust talent; avoid overreacting.

questions.text: Contract structure preference?

A.text: Two-year practical guarantees with clean outs.

questions.text: How do you manage locker room conflict?

B.text: Empower leaders to resolve it informally.

questions.text: How often should you brief ownership?

A.text: Weekly with metrics and action items.

questions.text: After a high-profile strategic mistake, what do you do?

A.text: Own it and change process immediately.

B.text: Defend it publicly; don’t show weakness.

scoring_engine.alignment_norm: alignment = clamp01( (alignment_raw - raw_min) / (raw_max - raw_min) ) where raw_min/max are computed from weights and delta bounds
scoring_engine.offer_rule: if interview_score>=0.80 premium; else if >=0.60 standard; else if >=0.45 conditional; else reject
tie_breakers: owner_ego_compatibility axis must be >= -2 cumulative for premium
accountability axis cumulative must be >= +10 for Elaine premium
media_sensitivity axis cumulative must be >= +6 for Marcus premium
